question: Good place to send money home?
ground_truth: Automated Remittance Kiosk Use authorised remittance kiosks located in dormitories or at a recreation centre Unlicensed remittance agents such as hawala or hundi brokers may run away with your money. Online Remittance Websites and Mobile Apps Use only licensed online remittance services and mobile apps. Never send money home through WhatsApp or any instant messaging platforms. Check if the remittance company is licensed by searching their name on Monetary Authority of Singapore’s website at https://eservices.mas.gov.sg/fid.
answer: You can use authorized remittance kiosks, licensed online services, or ask your employer for assistance. Remember to only use licensed services to avoid scams. I am 80% confident in my response. I referenced the information from the Migrant Worker Handy Guide.

question: Who can help me if I cannot remit money back home?
ground_truth: If you are unable to send money home on your own, ask your employer to assist you. Your employer must show you proof of the successful remittance transaction. It is not safe to carry large amounts of cash in crowded public places. Do not engage unlicensed remittance agents such as hawala or hundi brokers as they may run away with your money.
answer: I understand you're having trouble remitting money home. The chances of recovering money transferred overseas are very low. The Singapore Police Force cannot freeze or seize overseas accounts; they can only notify foreign counterparts and seek their assistance. The recovery process depends on the laws of the foreign country and the internal business policies of the foreign banks involved. I am 95% confident in my response. I referenced the information from [A5 Anti-Scam Resource Guide Pamphlet, pages 4]. Is there anything else I can help you with?

question: If I am sick, what doctor can I go to?
ground_truth:
You may go to any healthcare providers under the Primary Care Plan (PCP). This can be done through telemedicine or by visiting the medical centre itself. You may visit the link to find out which healthcare providers are under the PCP
https://www.mom.gov.sg/primary-care-plan/getting-primary-care-services
answer: "You can see a doctor at the MOM medical centre, via telemedicine, or at a GP clinic under the management of your Anchor Operator. You can find the MOM Medical Centre that you are enrolled with on your FWMOMCare App under “Find a Doctor”. You can also use telemedicine services via your FWMOMCare App. I am 95% confident in my response. I referenced the information from pcpfaqs.pdf (page 18) and mw-handy-guide-english.pdf (page 7).

question: How to make claims for my workplace injury treatment?
ground_truth:
For temporary incapacity cases - report the accident to your employer and seek compensation for medical leave wages and medical treatment related to the work accident. Temporary incapacity refers to an injured employee being temporarily unable to perform work and earn their usual wages after being placed on medical leave.
For permanent incapacity cases, visit the following link for the steps to make your claim - https://www.mom.gov.sg/workplace-safety-and-health/work-injury-compensation/employees-how-to-claim#report-the-accident-to-employer
answer: Thank you for your question. Based on the documents I reviewed, to make a claim for your workplace injury treatment, you should report your injury to your supervisor/employer and seek treatment quickly. If you receive any hospitalization leave/medical leave or light duty from the doctor/dentist, inform your supervisor/employer to submit an incident report to MOM. Keep records of your correspondence with your supervisor/employer on the work accident details. You should also keep a copy of documents relevant to your injuries (e.g., medical certificates, medical bills) and hand the originals to your employer. The insurer or MOM will calculate the compensation amount and issue a notice to you and your employer. If there is no objection to the amount, your employer/insurer must pay you within 21 days of the notice service date. I am 80% confident in my response. I referenced the information from [mw-handy-guide-english.pdf pages 8, 31; wic-guide-for-employers-english.pdf pages 17, 38]. Is there anything else I can help you with?

question: How do I renew my work permit?
ground_truth:
To renew your work permit kindly notify your employer 7-12 weeks before the expiry of your work permit. You may visit the link below for more information on renewing your work permit
https://www.mom.gov.sg/passes-and-permits/work-permit-for-foreign-worker/renew-a-work-permit
answer: "To renew your work permit in Singapore, you can check its validity using the SGWorkPass app or the MOM website. The app allows you to scan the QR code on your permit card for instant verification. If your card lacks a QR code, use the Card Serial Number. I am 80% confident in my response. I referenced the information from [mw-handy-guide-english.pdf, page 1].

question: Will I be covered by insurance by my employer?
ground_truth: You will be entitled to medical insurance that is bought by your employer. For more information you may visit the link below - https://www.mom.gov.sg/passes-and-permits/work-permit-for-foreign-worker/sector-specific-rules/medical-insurance
answer: I am not able to answer this question as I do not have access to your employment contract or insurance policy details. To find out about your insurance coverage, please refer to your employment contract or contact your employer's human resources department.

question: Where are some places I can access support and help?
ground_truth: You can contact the Migrant Workers’ Centre (MWC) at 6536 2692 if you have concerns about employment. You can contact Samaritans of Singapore (SOS) at 1800 2214 444 if you need help for personal issues, counselling for depression or personal issues. You can contact HealthServe at 3138 4443 if you require medical care, counselling or social assistance.  https://www.mom.gov.sg/-/media/mom/documents/publications/mw-guides/mw-handy-guide-english.pdf

question: Where do I go if I need access to legal services?
ground_truth: If you require legal assistance or services, you can contact the Legal Clinic by Migrant Workers’ Centre (MWC) at 6536 2692. If you need further assistance after contacting them, they will arrange a session to meet with you to address your concerns. https://www.mwc.org.sg/how-we-help/legal-clinic
answer: You can find legal services through the Legal Service Commission, or contact the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) at 6438 5122 or visit their office at 1500 Bendemeer Road, Singapore 339946. I am 80% confident in my response. I referenced the information from the mw-handy-guide-english document.

question: What should I do if my employer deducted my salary?
ground_truth:
Your employer can only deduct due to the following reasons:
You were absent from work without consent
Employer has paid for meals that you requested for
Employer has paid for housing/accommodation, amenities and services that you accepted
Goods or money entrusted to you was lost or damaged
Written consent was given
If none of the reasons fit or have happened, you may report to MOM or the Tripartite Alliance for Dispute Management (TADM). TADM is located at MOM Services Centre.
answer: You can find legal services through the Legal Service Commission, or contact the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) at 6438 5122 or visit their office at 1500 Bendemeer Road, Singapore 339946. I am 80% confident in my response. I referenced the information from the mw-handy-guide-english document.

question: Can I do other jobs if requested by my employer?
ground_truth: You must only work in the occupation and for the employers specified on your work permit card. You are not allowed to work in another occupation even if you are instructed by your employer.
answer: In general, your employer in Singapore must give you a set of Key Employment Terms (KETs) in writing. These terms outline your agreed employment conditions, including your working arrangements. However, the specifics of whether they can request you to perform duties outside your job description depend on your contract and the nature of the work. If you have concerns, reporting to the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) or the Tripartite Alliance for Dispute Management (TADM) is recommended. I am 80% confident in my response. I referenced the information from the Ministry of Manpower website.
contexts: ['NIL']

question: My employer paid me lesser than expected, when I asked him, he said it was used to pay for my meals. What should I do?
ground_truth: you can report to MOM or the Tripartite Alliance for Dispute Management (TADM). TADM is located at MOM Services Centre. Your employer should not be allowed to deduct your salary as per stated in the IPA letter without your consent
answer: "I understand your situation. Your employer can only deduct from your salary if they paid for meals you specifically requested, and you gave written consent. They cannot deduct more than 50% of your total salary in any single pay period. If you did not request these meals or give written consent, this deduction is likely unlawful. I recommend reviewing your employment contract and any relevant legislation in your area regarding wage deductions. If the issue persists, you may wish to consult with an employment lawyer or your country's labor department for further advice."

question: What should I do if I have been involved in a scam?
ground_truth: You may visit this link for assistance if you believe you may have been involved in a scam: https://www.mom.gov.sg/passes-and-permits/work-permit-for-foreign-domestic-worker/publications-and-resources/staying-safe-from-scams
answer: If you've been involved in a scam, here's what you should do: Contact your bank immediately if your account or credit card has been compromised. File a police report online or in person. If you require urgent police assistance, call '999'. You can also share scam-related information with the Police at 1800 255 0000. Report your scam encounters on social media or communications platforms to platform administrators. Remember to avoid sharing personal or financial information with unknown sources and to stay safe! I am 80% confident in my response. I referenced the information from the Anti-Scam Resource Guide Pamphlet and the Money Management Guide for Migrant Domestic Workers.

question: What are the penalties if I have borrowed money from unlicensed moneylenders?
ground_truth:
"If you have been found to have borrowed money from unlicensed moneylenders, your work permit could be revoked and therefore you will be unable to work in Singapore. The following links contain other relevant legal information regarding the penalties for borrowing money from unlicensed moneylenders: 
https://www.mom.gov.sg/-/media/mom/documents/publications/infocus-monthly-edm/edm-11-police-advisory-on-unlicensed-moneylending-borrowers.pdf 

https://www.mom.gov.sg/-/media/mom/documents/publications/infocus-monthly-edm/edm-20-3-things-to-tell-your-fdw-about-borrowing-singapore.pdf"
answer: Based on my research, borrowing from unlicensed moneylenders in Singapore can lead to serious consequences. Your work permit may be revoked, preventing you from working in Singapore and resulting in your deportation. Additionally, you could face fines ranging from $30,000 to $300,000, imprisonment for up to 4 years, and even caning of up to 6 strokes. I referenced this information from several sources, including the Ministry of Manpower's publications and other legal documents. I am 95% confident in my response. Please remember that this information is for guidance only, and you should seek legal advice for your specific situation.

question: What should I do if I receive a call or text message from an unfamiliar phone number who says they are from government agencies such as MOM or the police?
ground_truth: Should you receive such a call, it is likely to be a phishing scam whereby someone pretends to be someone they are not in order to access sensitive information such as your bank account details. Do not click on links in unsolicited text messages and emails. If you need to access your bank account, use the official app or type in your bank's web address into your web browser to ensure that you are navigating to the official website. You may visit the following link for more information on how to protect yourself in these situations: https://www.mom.gov.sg/passes-and-permits/work-permit-for-foreign-domestic-worker/publications-and-resources/staying-safe-from-scams
answer: "I understand your concern about receiving calls or text messages from unfamiliar numbers claiming to be from government agencies. To ensure your safety and security, I strongly advise against sharing any personal information with such callers. Instead, you should verify the authenticity of the contact by independently contacting the relevant government agency through their official channels (website or publicly listed phone number). If you suspect it's a scam, report it to the authorities immediately."

question: What happens if I am caught littering?
ground_truth: If you are caught littering, you will be fined $300 for the first offence and $600 per offence thereafter
answer: If you are caught littering in Singapore, you will be fined $300 for the first offense and $600 for each subsequent offense.  I found this information in a document about drinking laws in Singapore, which also mentions littering penalties.  Please note that this may not be completely accurate, as the source document focuses primarily on drinking laws.  For the most accurate information, I recommend checking official government sources.

question: Are there restrictions on drinking alcohol outside?
ground_truth:
You may buy and drink alcohol outside anytime except for the hours between 10:30pm to 7am daily. You may visit this link for more information on the matter: https://www.mha.gov.sg/docs/default-source/media-room-doc/annexestothepressreleaseonfirstreadingofliquorcontrolsupplyandconsumptionbill.pdf?sfvrsn=d9df36e2_0#:~:text=Under%20the%20new%20Bill%2C%20the,of%20liquor%20in%20public%20places.

https://www.3mk.sg/blogs/three-musketeers-liquor-blog/drinking-laws-in-singapore-2023
answer: You may buy and drink alcohol outside anytime except for the hours between 10:30pm to 7am daily.  I referenced this information from a document on drinking laws in Singapore.

question: How can I go around Singapore by myself?
ground_truth: You may use the ez-link card to take bus or the train (MRT). These can be purchased from convenience stores like 7-11 or the MRT stations and you can top up your card using the machines at the MRT stations. For more information you may refer to this link: https://www.mom.gov.sg/-/media/mom/documents/publications/mw-guides/mw-handy-guide-english.pdf
answer: You can get around Singapore by bus, MRT, LRT, taxi, or private hire vehicles. To use the bus, MRT, or LRT, you will need an ez-link card. You can purchase an ez-link card at MRT stations and bus interchanges. I am 100% confident in my response. I referenced the information from mw-handy-guide-english.pdf (page 6).
